channel.title: RNZ Media & Technology Headlines
channel.description: The Latest Media & Technology headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Facebook admits to scraping every Australian adult user's public photos and posts
item.description: The company does not offer Australians an opt-out option like it does in the EU, because it has not been required to do so under privacy law.

item.title: Who follows the carnivore diet in New Zealand?
item.description: Jessica Henrard's 3-year-old daughter Winter is one of the younger members of the carnivore community.

item.title: Media focus on small stuff in government's big-budget transport plan
item.description: Some media queried how the $33b national transport plan will be funded. Others highlighted aspects that barely dent the budget.

item.title: The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives: 'Soft-swinging' TikTokers share their story in new reality series
item.description: The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives picks up on a TikTok drama for the ages: a group of women embroiled in a Mormon swinging scandal.

item.title: Raygun's first interview: 'The energy and vitriol that people had was pretty alarming'
item.description: The Australian B-Girl was pilloried online and in mainstream media after her Olympic outing in Paris.

item.title: US Open: Medvedev shows the way with entertaining media conferences
item.description: Daniil Medvedev is intelligent on and off the tennis court - despite the occasional run-in with officials and obliterated racquets.

item.title: 'Goblincore' and 'Funeral doom' - one of the brains behind Spotify wrapped
item.description: You might not have heard of music brain Glenn McDonald, but you're almost certainly familiar with his work.

item.title: MMA fighter Janay Harding joins RNZ's TAHI podcast
item.description: "I'm a yapper ... might as well make that my job," she told new co-host So'omālō Iteni Schwalger.

item.title: Privacy Commissioner slams company for using pics of crying boy without consent
item.description: Privacy Commissioner has ruled the company, which has not been named, effectively turned the young boy into a "meme for profit".

item.title: Kylie Jenner did it: How hard is it to change your child's name in New Zealand?
item.description: Adrienne Madsen decided on the name Jordan for her son. Ten weeks later, Jordan seemed more like a Benjamin.

item.title: Refreshed Saturday Morning show
item.description: With a new start time of 7am, a new hour-long segment will discuss the major news stories of the week with journalists, correspondents and newsmakers.

item.title: Is sitting in the car 'self care'?
item.description: "If that is the best tool you have in your tool box that is telling you something," says a counsellor, sucking some air out of the #cartime balloon.

item.title: NZ Police finally has facial recognition policy - but is it strict enough?
item.description: It says there must be a delay between gathering the footage and analysing it, as the risks of live facial recognition "outweigh the potential benefits".

item.title: Mental health experts issue warning over reporting of Polkinghorne trial
item.description: Suicide prevention experts are urging the High Court in Auckland to consider the risks of reporting from the trial.

item.title: Can you get ketamine for depression in New Zealand?
item.description: Todd Hilleard tried half a dozen different antidepressants before turning to much less common prescription.

item.title: Media moguls and the 'loophole' in democracy they exploit
item.description: A new breed of media owner wields greater power than the likes of Rupert Murdoch, an Australian editor says.

item.title: Why have we started outsourcing (almost) everything?
item.description: Some homes are outsourcing domestic duties and personal decisions to streamline their lives.

item.title: The Kiwi brain behind the Paris Olympic's medal per capita tally
item.description: Turns out the Medals Per Capita website is a nice bit of Kiwi propaganda.
